Change has been successfully merged
The idea looks good, but I have some concerns. What goals is this change designed to accomplish? I'm not sure what the improvement will be.
I agree here that using a union is a micro-optimization that did not seem necessary. The structures don't take up that much space.
No action needed here, marking this as Resolved

We must also continue to test for NAN here. Please do not remove the NAN test. Reason is, NAN is used as an indication of an error, a missing sensor reading, or similar.

This also reminds me of a historical bug here. We should be using std::isfinite() instead of isnan() here, because that will give us the advantage of being able to also catch other weird floating-point error states like +INF and -INF.

Do you suggest that we should have the following change?
if (std::isnan(lastInput)) => if (std::isfinite(lastInput))
Done

This entire block looks like a pretty significant behavioral change. I'm unsure what's going on here. What is the purpose of this change? Will it break people's existing PID loops that they already have working in their hardware?

Hi Josh,

In Meta OpenBMC, the PID controller would use input temperature and setpoint to check the hysteresis instead of using input temperature and last input temperature.

And the PID controller would not calculate the output PWM if the input temperature was lower than the setpoint and will reset the integral term if the input temperature was lower than the setpoint to prevent the overshot.

I think it is different behavior than existing PID loops. Should we add an option for user to choose which method they need?

Ref:https://github.com/facebook/openbmc/blob/helium/common/recipes-core/fscd3/fscd/fsc_control.py#L23

Yes, this should be an option. A compile-time option is fine. Reason is, I don't want to break anybody's existing PID loops, which could be very delicately tuned, by doing anything that changes the default behavior of the computations.

(To contrast, adding new optional features that don't change the behavior by default, such as introducing the "D" term, is always completely OK, because these don't alter existing behavior.)
I added a compile flag to seperate two methods to calculate PID output.
This new behavior should have documentation/examples documented somewhere. See also my similar comment below.

Hi Josh,
In Meta OpenBMC, we could set stepwise controller and PID controller in fan table for one sensor. The output PWM will be calculated by accumulating stepwise PWM and PID PWM.
Therefore, we propose to accumulate the output PWM that the controllers have same profile name. E.g. The profile name of PID_Temp_CPU0 and Stepwise_Temp_CPU0 are Temp_CPU0.

Ref: https://github.com/facebook/openbmc/blob/helium/meta-facebook/meta-fby35/recipes-fby35/fscd/fscd/FSC_CLASS1_type1_zone1.fsc#L2

This is useful information. Please add documentation somewhere, to explain the usage of this new feature? Adding it to your Gist would be sufficient. Others might be interested in using this new feature as well.

Update gist.
https://gist.github.com/DelphineCCChiu/a6170d3e1a12fc4ee76fad324382fba3
Good elaboration
I'm not sure what this is to accomplish. What is the purpose of this? Also, please provide documentation/examples for this new feature.

We would like to accumulate the output PWM of PID controller and stepwise controller so the maximum setpoint name would be the combination of the name of PID controller and the name of stepwise controller.
Makes sense, based on what was explained in other comments
I am unsure of the purpose of adding the string field here. What additional purpose does this string serve?

We would like to accumulate the output PWM of PID controller and stepwise controller so we would accumulate the setpoint of the controllers that have same profile name.
E.g. The profile name of PID_Temp_CPU0 and Stepwise_Temp_CPU0 are Temp_CPU0.
Interesting. I don't quite understand what is meant by "accumulate the setpoint" in this context. How do the two PID loops interact?

We can have multiple controllers for same sensors, as you can see in the reference fan table. It has two controllers, linear_cpu (which is stepwise) and pid_cpu, to monitor the temperature of CPU.

We will accumulate the output PWM(setpoint) of linear_cpu and pid_cpu as the output PWM for CPU temperature.

There is a setpoint 65 degree in pid_cpu that means the output PWM of pid_cpu will be 0 if the temperature was lower than 65 degree.

Once the temperature was over 65 degree, the linear_cpu will ouput 40 PWM and pid_cpu will also calculate the output PWM, let's say pid_cpu_output. The output PWM for CPU temperature will be 40 + pid_cpu_output.

Ref: https://github.com/facebook/openbmc/blob/helium/meta-facebook/meta-fby35/recipes-fby35/fscd/fscd/FSC_CLASS1_type1_config.json#L61

Interesting, so the PWM would be cumulative, and the sum total of the PWM from each loop would be added together and then sent to the fan motor? What happens if the sum total exceeds 100%, is it capped?

So the purpose of this is to unify a feature from the Facebook fork of OpenBMC with the mainline OpenBMC? This is a good idea.

However, since it will affect existing behavior, I am really hoping to see it safely isolated behind a flag, so that this differing behavior will only be enabled if the user has explicitly configured it to be so.

I also noticed the Facebook files have different field names. For example, "kp", "ki", "kd", instead of "PCoefficient", "ICoefficient", "DCoefficient".

Hi Josh,

The output PWM can be limited by the output maximum clamp value in fan table so it won't exceed 100%.

I added a compile flag to seperate two method to calculate PID output.
Thanks for adding a compile-time flag to separate out the new behavior.

I would prefer this stay a vector. If you wish to ensure that no duplicates are present, how about checking for them at insertion time, and making sure that a duplicate does not already exist before inserting it?
Done
This text is good, but please maintain the line wrap at 72 characters. For a lengthy commit message, a link to a GitHub Gist might be useful, instead of putting it all in the message.

Done
I don't really understand about this option, can you give some example json?

Hi Harvey,
The accumulateSetPoint could be added in the 'zones' filed in fan table.

>    "zones" : [
>        {
>            "id": 1,
>            "failsafePercent": 90.0,
>            "minThermalOutput": 0.0,
>            "accumulateSetPoint": true,
>            "pids": [
>                {
>                 ...

Hi Harvey,
Would like to know if you have any concern about this design?

If I understand correctly,
after enabling accumulateSetPoint, if adding stepwise and PID controllers to CPU_temp, when temp < setpoint, the output value is controlled by stepwise, and when temp > setpoint, the output value is controlled by PID.
Is this correct?

Hi Harvey,
After enabling accumulateSetPoint, the output PWM of stepwise and pid controller could be accumulated if they have same profile name.

After adding the compile flag "check-hysteresis-using-setpoint", PID contorller won't calculate PWM when temp < setpoint.

If enable accumulateSetPoint and add the compile flag, when temp < setpoint, the output value is controlled by stepwise, and when temp > setpoint, the output value is controlled by PID and stepwise.
Thanks for the explanation.

Please also implement to dbusconfiguration.
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-pid-control/+/57660/comments/ef293a07_b1e70c8c
Ok, I'll implement to dbusconfiguration. Thanks!
Done
Maybe need to use "const" to setpt and input?
Done
Seems to need to set the default value if not found this setting in json like dbusconfiguration.
Done

Sorry for the delay. It's true that this has taken a long time. I have no further objections that are significant enough to delay this further.

The unfortunate side-effect of this patch is we end up with code that isn't compiled by default in CI.  Is there any way to consolidate the two sides of this #ifdef in a way where the configuration option can be dropped.  Why does this behavior need to be two different compile options rather than specified in the JSON?
Revised to use `checkHysterWithSetpt` flag in pid info.
Please mark this as Resolved if it's fixed.
Done

This part of the change isn't obvious.  `NaN` is an explicit value which we use elsewhere for "undefined" and that is what the comment on line 78 suggests.  You've changed it to "not finite" which means that infinite values are now also covered.  It gives the impression that that fixes something you've not documented.
Modified the annotation.
Please mark this as Resolved if it's fixed.
Done

It isn't obvious why you've chosen `lowest` over `min`.

What if input is non-finite or NaN?

Agreed, this looks like a magic number flag. This is something that is explicitly not needed with floating-point numbers, as we have `NaN` to indicate "not available" or "not initialized yet". Please use these instead.
Revised to use min.

I still don't like the idea of using `min()` or `max()` as flag values here, to indicate uninitialized input. Please use `NaN` as a sentinel/placeholder value as required. Use `std::numeric_limits<double>::quiet_NaN()` as an initializer. This is what is already being done by the rest of the program, to indicate invalid/uninitialized/empty values safely. Please use `isfinite()` to test for validity.

The purpose to use `lowest()` and `max()` is that the initial value set in `ThermalController::inputProc` is `std::numeric_limits<double>::max()` or `std::numeric_limits<double>::lowest()`.

Do you think that we need to check if the `input` from `ThermalController::inputProc` is valid here?

Hi Josh,
Would like to ask do you have any suggestions about this.

Since the input from both `ThermalController::inputProc` and `FanController::inputProc` have been checked with `isfinite()`.
And the input would be set with setpoint if the value is not acceptable in `ThermalController::inputProc`.
Therefore, removed the conditional here.
That is acceptable behavior to me, thanks. As you noted, the validation checks are already being made elsewhere, so checking them again here is not necessary (and it can be confusing or misleading).
Why is const added here?  This has no bearing on the ABI or API since these doubles are POD.
Agreed, and these doubles are being passed in by copy, so `const` here has no effect, and needlessly constrains the caller.
Removed.
Looks like the CI Build failure is not related to this commit.
The Jenkins error is from `phosphor-softpoweroff` which is not the subject of this change. I would ask around on Discord if Jenkins continues to fail.

Hi
Would like to ask is there any other questions about this commit?
Nope, looks good to me! Thanks to Patrick Williams for also reviewing it.
